question: Outline ONE strength and ONE limitation of the Arrhenius definition of acids and bases.

sample_answer.full_answer: Strength: It links acids and bases to observable changes in aqueous conductivity and neutralisation (1 mark). Limitation: It only applies to aqueous solutions and cannot explain gas-phase acid-base reactions (1 mark).

marking_criteria.criteria: States a correct advantage of the Arrhenius model linked to aqueous behaviour.
Identifies a limitation such as restriction to aqueous systems or inability to define NH3 as a base in non-water solvents.

common_mistakes: Saying Arrhenius works for all reactions.
Failing to mention the aqueous requirement.

question: Explain why ammonia is classified as a Brønsted-Lowry base but not an Arrhenius base.

sample_answer.full_answer: Ammonia accepts a proton from water to form NH4+ (Brønsted-Lowry base) (1 mark). It does not contain OH- to release into solution, so it does not fit the Arrhenius requirement of producing OH- directly (1 mark). The hydroxide ions appear because water donates a proton, not because NH3 supplies OH- (1 mark).

marking_criteria.criteria: Describes NH3 accepting a proton to form ammonium.
States Arrhenius requires direct production of OH-.
Clarifies that OH- forms due to water's role, not ammonia releasing hydroxide.

common_mistakes: Claiming ammonia releases hydroxide ions directly.
Not mentioning the role of water.

question: Acetic acid reacts with ammonia in the gas phase to form ammonium acetate. Identify the acid and base under the Brønsted-Lowry and Lewis models. Justify your selection.

sample_answer.full_answer: Brønsted-Lowry: Acetic acid (CH3COOH) donates a proton to NH3, so it is the acid. Ammonia accepts the proton, so it acts as the base (2 marks). Lewis: NH3 donates an electron pair to the proton; when the proton is bound to acetate it accepts the pair, so NH3 is the Lewis base and H+ (carried by acetate) is the Lewis acid (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: Correctly assigns Brønsted-Lowry acid and base with justification referencing proton transfer.
Correctly assigns Lewis acid and base with justification referencing electron pair donation/acceptance.

common_mistakes: Calling acetate the base under Brønsted-Lowry because it is a salt product.
Not distinguishing between proton and electron pair viewpoints.

question: Compare how the Brønsted-Lowry and Lewis models explain the reaction between hydrogen fluoride and boron trifluoride.

sample_answer.full_answer: In the Brønsted-Lowry model, HF can donate a proton to become F- while BF3 cannot accept a proton, so the reaction is not easily described (2 marks). The Lewis model classifies BF3 as an electron pair acceptor and F- as an electron pair donor, forming the adduct F3B<-F- (2 marks).

marking_criteria.criteria: States that Brønsted-Lowry struggles to describe the reaction because no proton transfer to BF3 occurs.
Explains how Lewis acid-base theory accounts for the electron pair donation from fluoride to boron.

common_mistakes: Claiming Brønsted-Lowry describes the reaction without acknowledging the limitations.
Omitting the formation of a coordinate covalent bond.

question: Evaluate the usefulness of the Lewis definition for explaining the catalytic action of aluminium chloride (AlCl3) in the polymerisation of ethene. Include the mechanism for 1 propene molecule interacting with the catalyst.

sample_answer.full_answer: Lewis theory treats AlCl3 as an electron pair acceptor because Al has an empty orbital (1 mark). Propene donates electron density from its double bond to AlCl3 forming a complex that polarises the C=C bond (2 marks). This generates a carbocation that can attack another propene molecule, initiating polymerisation (2 marks). The Arrhenius or Brønsted-Lowry models cannot describe this behaviour because no proton transfer or OH- production occurs (1 mark).

marking_criteria.criteria: Identifies AlCl3 as a Lewis acid with an empty orbital.
Describes electron pair donation from the alkene to AlCl3 forming a complex and polarising the bond.
Links the complex to carbocation formation and subsequent polymerisation step.

common_mistakes: Referencing proton transfer instead of electron donation.
